further grasping them as the cause is like two feet.
Grasping precepts must have these two characteristics, otherwise it is included in wrong views.
There is no need to specifically match the two graspings of the upper realms, because the other afflictions are not said to be common to the upper realms.

Although they cling to seeking the supramundane cessation fruit, they are called going because they leave the names of birth in the human and heavenly realms, they are called returning because they still sink in evil destinies, they are called wandering because they always sink in birth and death and their efforts are in vain, they are called indulging because they cling to it as supreme and deviate from the right path, they are called playing because they cling to it as the right cause and become attached to birth and death.
The sÅ«tra says: Grabbing a dog by its two front legs, beating it, and enjoying the dog's fear.
The commentary says:
This specifically clarifies the characteristics of their practices.
The nirvÄá¹‡a and liberation sought by non-Buddhists are not true and supreme dharmas.

Birth and death are as despicable as a dog. Obtaining their precepts and observances is like grabbing its two front legs. Because nirvÄá¹‡a is the cause, it is like the legs. Precepts and observances are different, so they are called two.
Or it is called two because they cling to it as supreme and as the cause.
Firmly adhering to precepts and observances is like grabbing a dog's legs. Practicing in accordance with oneself is like knocking the legs over.
Knocking is pronounced as pu in the tone of jiu. It means to knock over.
The Tongsuwen says: Struggling and knocking over is called 'pu'.
Some write it as pu pronounced as pu boå, meaning to strike.
The YÃ¹piÄn says it means to strike or to slap with the hands.
This is not the meaning here, nor is it the character pu.
Proclaiming the practice of austerities and nirvana to sentient beings, as if causing them to lose their voice.
Clinging to precepts and observances as able to reach nirvana, like adding a dog's foot to a dog's neck.

Using this to peacefully practice austerities in order to seek nirvana, the meaning is the same as frightening a dog and not letting go, even calling it suffering but considering it joy, because it entertains one's own feelings, it is called self-enjoyment.
The sÅ«tra says: Again, there are ghosts who cry out and seek food.
The commentary says:
This is a metaphor for the view of the self.
The innate view of the self has always been present since beginningless time, so it is called large.
The view of the self that arises from discrimination is associated with unwholesome natures and shamelessness, which is likened to being naked.
Naked means exposed, because of having no sense of shame.
Covered by ignorance, it is called black, and deluded about the correct principles, it is called emaciated.
Firmly grasping the five aggregates, never letting go for a moment, it is called dwelling in permanence.
The causes of afflictions arise from this, and the grasping of self-identity arises from this, called emitting evil sounds.
Extensively giving rise to views of self everywhere, it grows like a cry for food.
The sÅ«tra says: There are also ghosts whose throats are like needles.
The commentary praises:
This illustrates the view of grasping.
Their heads are like mountains, and their throats are extremely small like the eye of a needle, unable to accept food;

The view of grasping is also like this. Grasping one's own views and so forth as the cause and the supreme, it is considered great like a mountain, and does not accept other views like the extreme smallness of a needle.
The sÅ«tra says: There are also ghosts who eat only vomit, or who eat only dogs.
The commentary praises:
The following two verses illustrate extreme views, divided into two parts:
The first verse illustrates the general characteristics, and the second verse illustrates the specific characteristics.
This is the first.
Heads like ox heads means the head has two horns, seeing the middle as either eternal or annihilated.
Eternality and annihilation must arise after the view of self, like how there are two horns based on the ox head.
Or eating human flesh is a metaphor for the view of annihilation, because the harm to good is deep due to grasping annihilation, and one is completely unwilling to cultivate, like eating human flesh.
Or eating dogs is a metaphor for the view of eternality, because it does not obstruct the arising of good and the harm is shallow, like eating dogs.
The sutra says: With disheveled hair, they howl and run around.
The commentary says:
This is a metaphor for the specific characteristics of their activities.
Based on this extreme view, forty-seven of the sixty-two views arise, like disheveled hair.
Because of this view, they mutually slander each other with the non-Buddhists, like the danger of being harmed.
The false views of non-Buddhists are called danger, so danger means evil and perilous.
Because they lack the nourishment of the food of the correct teachings and the water of proper principles, they are oppressed by hunger and thirst.
If the inner mind is like this, the external manifestation of sound attachment is like shouting, and the body urgently following it is like running.
The sutra says: Yakshas, hungry ghosts, and various evil birds and beasts, all come to the windows to watch, frightened and terrified.
The commentary says:
This concludes the above.ğŸ”½Because non-Buddhists give rise to afflictions and false inverted views, they are like yakshas and hungry ghosts.
Because those in the secular world give rise to afflictions and attachments out of ignorance, they are like various evil birds and beasts.
This summarizes what was explained above. Because of giving rise to those, one does not understand the correct principles.
Lacking wisdom is like being hungry and urgent. In the secular world, one encounters the four states of birth, old age, sickness, and death.
Everywhere one encounters unfavorable conditions, giving rise to delusions, like being hungry and urgent in the four directions.

Non-Buddhists cannot correctly view the causes and conditions of nirvana. They engage in false practices and observe the correct principles, like looking through a window. Because of improper practice,
there are innumerable difficulties and fears. This briefly explains suffering and delusions.
If the difficulties are still like this, how much more so are the evil karmas? How can the analogies be exhausted?
To peek is written as to spy, which means to look at something with a small gaze.
In general, when people secretly look at each other, in the southern state of Chu it is called to spy.
The sÅ«tra says, This dilapidated old house, the flames all blazing together.
The commentary says:
Below, in ten and a half verses, it specifically clarifies the reasons for the confusion and chaos caused by the insects and ghosts.
There are three parts:

First, two verses clarify that when the master is present there are no calamities, and when the master is absent calamities arise. Next, one verse clarifies that due to the burning fire the house is destroyed and collapses. The last seven and a half verses belong to this confusion and chaos caused by the insects and ghosts.
This is the first part of the text.
To belong is pronounced as zhu yu fan. To belong means to be related.

The meaning is that when the Bodhisattva is in the house during the stage of causes, and after becoming a Buddha is in the world benefiting beings, the calamities and difficulties of birth and death and afflictions cease.
When the Buddha enters nirvÄá¹‡a, the Bodhisattvas disappear and the benefit to beings is suspended, and the calamities and difficulties of birth and death and afflictions then arise.
It is also because when the master is in the house strictly managing and weaving, exhorting the children, calamities and difficulties do not arise;
If the master leaves the house and no one repairs it, then with no one to encourage the children, they will be negligent and disasters will arise, causing the house to collapse.

Therefore, the house of the three realms, due to the Buddha being present, disasters do not arise. Due to the Buddha being absent, disasters arise. Thus, it is said to belong to one person, which is a metaphor for the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.
It is not due to non-Buddhist paths, but only due to the Buddha's teachings, thus it is said to be one person.
Moreover, belongs is pronounced as shi zhu in reverse. Belongs means to be included.
The three realms are all that belongs to the Buddha. It is said that the Buddha is the master, because they all belong to the Buddha.
The person has recently gone out means entering nirvana and hiding, leaving the birth of the three realms, which is called recently going out, like a house without an owner.
Suddenly a fire breaks out is a metaphor for the afflictions damaging the body and faculties, like fire damaging a house.
It should be the character belongs.
Having it without a beginning is called suddenly a fire breaking out.
From birth to death, all that is encountered arises, called the four sides at the same time.
Because of this, immeasurable evil karma arises, called flaming and burning.
The sÅ«tra says: The beams, pillars, rafters, and walls collapse.
The commentary says:
Because of the burning fire, the house is destroyed and collapses.
Beams and pillars refer to the aggregate of feeling.
Rafters refer to the bones and joints, which are the aggregate of form.
Pillars refer to the aggregate of mental formations.
Exploding sounds are a metaphor for the suffering of birth.
Explode is pronounced as bo jiao fan, meaning the fire is deep and intense.
It is also pronounced as pu bo fan. The Shuowen says it means to scorch and spread out.
The YÃ¹piÄn has three pronunciations: bu juÃ©, pu juÃ©, and pÃº juÃ©, all meaning to scorch and heat.
It is also written as pÃ¡o, meaning to rise up in anger.
In ancient times, it was written as two forms: zhÃ¬ and pÃ¡o, with the same pronunciation.ğŸ”½Shaking and cracking is a metaphor for the suffering of old age.
Shaking means the meaning of startling and trembling. The suffering of old age in the body is like thunder startling and trembling, which is very frightening.
Or it is written as zhen.
Crushing and breaking is a metaphor for the suffering of illness, which crushes and breaks the body and life, causing the prime of life to wither.
Falling down is a metaphor for the suffering of death, because it destroys life.
Birth, old age, sickness, and death, together with the pillars, are the impermanence of the aggregate of formations.
The reason for explaining the four characteristics after the three aggregates and before the aggregate of perception is to show that birth, etc., are universal to the five aggregates.
Walls and pillars collapsing is a metaphor for the impermanence inside and outside the aggregate of perception.
The impermanence of the four aggregates of feeling, form, formations, and perception is present in the house of consciousness.

The previous text has already explained that the fire arises in the house, generally speaking of the five aggregates having birth, old age, sickness, and death, impermanence, decay, and destruction, which are deeply to be detested.
Question:
The calamities in the house are all afflictions. Why are they sometimes called fire and sometimes called insects and ghosts?
Answer:
Burning and oppressing the body and mind is likened to fire, and ignorance and harm are compared to insects and ghosts.
In order to cause them to be frightened and disgusted, various analogies are given.
Consciousness is the basis, likened to a house;
Afflictions arise based on it, thus it is compared to fire insects.
The four aggregates are all the dependent, thus it is said that they are destroyed by fire, but it is not said that insects and ghosts also depend on fire to move.
The sutra says: The various ghosts and spirits, etc., are unable to escape by themselves.
The commentary says:
Below, seven and a half verses belong to this chaotic disturbance by insects and ghosts.
There are three parts:

One and a half verses are analogies for the calamities of the desire realm, three and a half verses are analogies for the calamities of the form realm, and two and a half verses are analogies for the calamities of the formless realm.
This is the first.
The various ghosts and spirits are analogies for the renunciant non-Buddhists and lay Buddhists in the desire realm.
Afflicted by various sufferings, they raise their voices and cry out, etc. This includes insects and beasts.
Therefore the Dashabhumika-shastra says:
Non-Buddhists know about birth, old age, sickness, and death, and give rise to disgust, thus they raise their voices and cry out.
Now it is extended to include lay people.
Moreover, lay people give rise to greed and so forth, which leads to quarrels, while non-Buddhists give rise to various views, which also leads to quarrels.
Raising their voices and shouting is the general phrase.ğŸ”½Because of giving rise to greed and so forth, which are dull afflictions, they are like vultures and other birds of prey;
Because of giving rise to various views, which are sharp and quick afflictions, they are like kumbhÄá¹‡á¸as and other demons.
This is the specific phrase.
Although they are afflicted by suffering and raise their voices and shout,

lay people are distressed because of foolishness and love, while non-Buddhist renunciants use suffering to try to abandon suffering. All of these are called frantically terrified, unable to escape on their own.
Frantic means agitated and frightened.
It is also written as zhÄng.
Zhou means to flow, the state of flowing everywhere in confusion and fear, feeling uneasy.
Below there is frantically terrified, which should be written as zhÅuzhÄng. Because of the frantic below, zhÅuzhÄng is already implied.
This should be written as zhÄng, which also means to be frightened and terrified.
Fear means to be frightened, thus to be startled and terrified.
This is based on the first interpretation of shouting loudly.

If based on the latter interpretation, because worldly people and non-Buddhists give rise to sharp and dull afflictions and constantly quarrel, with this haste in birth and death and anxiety in the morning and evening, how could they know that the fire of afflictions will burn and harm them by insects and ghosts, and seek liberation?
Even if they wish to seek liberation, there is no way to attain it on their own.
The sutra says: Evil beasts and poisonous insects also dwell there.
The commentary says:
The next three and a half verses are a metaphor for the calamities in the form realm.
There are three parts:

One verse is a metaphor for worldly people and non-Buddhists both being born in that realm, one verse is a metaphor for although there is pure concentration that subdues afflictions, the afflictions still arise, and one verse and a half is a metaphor for although seeking to leave desire, grasping it as supreme, the afflictions arise again.
This is the first.
The concentration of the form realm is deep, like a hole.
Being born there as a layperson is like an insect hiding in it.
Because they are born from non-Buddhist paths and ghosts, it says also abide.
Cun is pronounced as qiuanå, meaning to flee.
The YÃ¹piÄn says to hide, to cover.
The sÅ«tra says: Because of their meager blessings and virtues, they drink blood and eat meat.
The commentary says:
This analogy shows that although they have pure samÄdhi to subdue afflictions, the afflictions arise again.
The sages have pure samÄdhi, but afflictions do not arise;

Although they have pure samÄdhi, they lack true blessings and wisdom, called meager blessings and virtues. They are further burned by afflictions such as greed, delusion, pride, doubt, views of the body, and extreme views, called fire afflictions.
They are unable to eradicate these afflictions and still give rise to views of grasping, mutually denouncing each other, called mutual harm.
Grasping their own superior path is like drinking blood, because their views are subtle.
Giving rise to the grasping of precepts and firmly adhering to them is like eating meat, because the matters are coarse.ğŸ”½Eat is pronounced as tuÅ gÄƒn fÄƒn, meaning to eat.
Some write it as dÃ n tÃºn gÄƒn fÄƒn.
SÅ«tra: The jackals and their kind, having already died, the various fierce beasts compete to eat them, filling the four directions.
Commentary:
Although seeking to leave desire, grasping that as supreme, afflictions arise again.
Jackals are doubts in the desire realm.
Their kind are the remaining afflictions.
All have already died means they were previously subdued and eliminated.
Due to grasping concentration as supreme, giving rise to various afflictions such as craving, views, pride, and doubts in the form realm, called great fierce beasts.
These increase and grow, like competing to come and eat.
The flames of afflictions burning, scorching even more widely, afflictions born from concentration are unenjoyable like foul smoke.
Foul smoke proliferating is called smoke.
The sound of smoke is pronounced as pang hong in reverse.
There are only two characters, poluo and feng zhen, with qi like disheveled pampas grass.
It should be the character feng.
Some make it the character peng.
According to the YÅ­piÄn, it is the same as the bÅng in bÅnghuo, and also does not have the sound of pÄ“ng.
XÄ« is pronounced like bÅ mÃ² fÇn, meaning large and flourishing.
If dust arises, it makes xÄ«.
Fire incense makes xÄ«.
The present foul smell is like the pÄ“ng being abundant and chaotic, or the foul qi greatly rising like pÄ“ng.
Some make the character xÄ«, not knowing where it comes from.
It arises in the four concentrations, and there is no place without it, like being filled on all four sides.
The sÅ«tra says: centipedes, millipedes... take whatever they can get and eat it.
The commentary says:
The next two and a half verses are a metaphor for the calamity in the formless realm.
The first verse and a half is a metaphor for the afflictions of the lower three grounds, and the last verse is a metaphor for the afflictions that arise in the summit of existence.
This is the first.

Centipedes and other such creatures are metaphors for ordinary beings, burned by the fire of afflictions in the lower form realm, seeking to be born in the formless realm like leaving their burrows to be born in the lower three places.
KumbhÄá¹‡á¸a ghosts are used as a metaphor for those non-Buddhists.
Non-Buddhists often grasp the two upper realms as nirvÄá¹‡a.
They deny that ordinary beings grasp them as a special nirvÄá¹‡a, and because of the ordinary beings they give rise to delusions, like ghosts who see worms and eat them as they please.
Eating means the meaning of nourishing and supporting, because as they follow the arising of those delusions they increase even more.
The sÅ«tra says, Moreover, all hungry ghosts...
The commentary says:
This metaphor is for the afflictions at the peak of existence.
The non-Buddhists born there are called hungry ghosts.
Because of the three peaks of existence, it is called on the head.
The further arising of afflictions is called burning with fire.
Lacking the nourishment of the correct teachings and the sustenance of the water of the Dharma, it is called hungry and thirsty.
Being oppressed by afflictions is like being in distress.
Constantly in an uneasy state, it is called wandering around.
Wandering around means the meaning of wandering around.
Falling back into the five destinies is called running around in confusion.
Some texts have barren, which means the meaning of being frightened.
The above explanation of the parable is intended to cause one to detest and fear the various changing names, and the wise should understand them.
The scripture says: The house was like this, with many difficulties.
The commentary says:
This text is the third conclusion of the above difficulties.
Since the difficulties are numerous, they cannot be fully described.
The sound zhong has two pronunciations:
Zhi-long and Zhi-zhong.
The scripture says: At that time, the owner of the house was standing outside the gate.
The commentary says:
Below is the third major section with fourteen verses, the parable of seeing and devising expedient means.
The prose section has four parts, and this section is also like that.

The first three verses are the parable of seeing suffering and giving rise to compassion, the next five verses are the parable of showing the great vehicle but not being receptive, the next three verses are the parable of contemplating and rescuing, and the last three verses are the parable of correctly expounding the three vehicles.
The first text has two parts:
The first two verses are about seeing suffering, and the last verse is about giving rise to compassion.

The first two lines in the section on seeing suffering are a metaphor for the Buddha's emergence from the three realms, and the next one and a half verses are a metaphor for hearing again the pitiful events of sentient beings dwelling in difficult places.
This is the first text.
Master means intimate, superior, in charge, leading, and guarding.
There are two kinds of gates:
The first is the teaching gate, and the second is the practice gate.

The Buddha abides in the fruition and emerges from outside the causal gate, which is the position dwelling in the wondrous principle, and is also the principle emerging from the teaching gate and the gate of the One Vehicle, therefore it is said outside the gate.
Because the prose section says Although I am able to safely escape from this burning house, now it is said to be standing outside, there are four meanings:
First, the appearance of dwelling and waiting, waiting for the children to come out of the house;
Second, the appearance of about to act, about to act and enter to save, therefore it is called standing;
Third, standing is the appearance of not acting, waiting for the opportunity to mature and about to rescue, therefore not immediately acting;

To establish means the meaning of arising and accomplishing. Sentient beings are in samsara, not yet arisen and not yet accomplished, like sitting. The Buddha has already arisen and accomplished, so he establishes.
The sutra says: Hearing someone say... up to ...joyfully indulging and attached.
The commentary says:
This metaphor illustrates hearing about sentient beings being in difficulty.
The previous prose section says the elder sees this great fire, the chapter on skillful means says I observe with the Buddha eye, and now it says hearing has two meanings:

First, the self and others are reflected, not only seeing sentient beings drowning in suffering, but also hearing what is transmitted by other buddhas of the three times. The near and distant are revealed.
Second, the eyes see suffering and arise, because it is close, it is called seeing. The Dharma waits for the opportunity to save, because it is distant, it is called hearing.
From beginningless time, unrestrained and running wild, giving rise to afflictions and discrimination, is called previously playing.
Experiencing the fruits of suffering in the three realms is called coming into this house.
From beginningless time, due to afflictions and karma, one experiences consciousness and so forth, turning one's back on principle and deviating from truth, which is called entering.
Entering means the meaning of dwelling, not that it is now called entering because it was previously exiting.
That cultivation of the factors of liberation is called exiting, but because one does not cultivate, it is called entering.
The lineage of the three vehicles has not yet manifested, and even if one gives rise to the great aspiration, one retreats and seeks the lesser fruit, which is called childish.
Childish is pronounced as zhi li fan, meaning young and weak.
Covered by foolishness and ignorance, it is called ignorance.
Carelessly indulging the six senses in this suffering result, it is called delighting.
Craving and being attached to various objects, it is called enjoyment.
The sutra says: The elder, having heard this, will make them free from burning and harm.
The commentary says:
This praises the arising of compassion as a metaphor.
The compassion that arises from entering the house to save them is called alarm.
Following along with birth and death, it is called entering the burning house.

Because of this entry, later they also come out at the same time as their children. They go around to rescue, not caring about the difficulties, called should rescue and help, because they help in a timely manner.
The sÅ«tra says: Advising the children, saying... and so on, up to ...continuously without interruption.
The commentary praises:
Below are five verses comparing the reluctance to accept the great [vehicle].
There are two parts:
The first four verses secretly show the many sufferings in order to bestow the great vehicle, and the last verse shows the fearlessness in accepting the great [vehicle].
The first part has two further divisions:
The first verse and a half generally announce that delusions and suffering will arise again, and the last two verses and a half specifically announce the evil realms to be detested.
This is the first [division].
Speaking of the many difficulties refers to the destruction of the house, the fire disaster, and the chaos of insects and ghosts.
Evil ghosts refers to the various views of non-Buddhists.
Poisonous insects refers to the remaining delusions of laypeople.
These two serve as conditions, and all the afflictions and disasters that arise continue without interruption.
Continuous means a continuous appearance.
Some explain it as going up and down, calling it a flat sound. It is like grass vines, and also like the length of a mat.
Or it is extended, like grass vines that extend and continue without interruption.
Or vines is pronounced as wang yuan.
Mat is pronounced as yu zhan.
The Western Capital Fu says, Its form is like vines.
The Guangya says, Vines mean long.
Mat means everywhere, both pronounced with the departing tone, like the meaning of wild fire spreading continuously without end.
It arises from the house fire, so it is called fire vines.
Because the burning house is destroyed, it is called suffering.
The sequence continues without end. This meaning shows that suffering arises from delusion.
In dependent origination, after ignorance and karmic formations, there are the five beginning with consciousness.
After craving, grasping, and becoming, there is birth, aging, and death.
Because suffering gives rise to delusion, birth and death continue without end.
After contact and feeling, there is craving and grasping.
After old age and death, there is again ignorance, thus the cycle of birth and death is called revolving.
The sÅ«tra says: Poisonous snakes, vipers, and scorpions...
The commentary says:
This is a separate announcement.
Poisonous snakes and so on refer to anger.
Yaká¹£as refer to evil karma.
KumbhÄá¹‡á¸as refer to adherence to precepts.
Jackals refer to doubt.ğŸ”½Dogs refer to pride.
Vultures refer to craving and love.
A hundred legs and so on refer to various afflictions.
Since they lack the food of the Dharma, they are born with hunger and thirst, and the urgency of distress is extremely frightening.

Seeing their deluded appearances - this is a place of suffering and extreme evil, already unpleasant, let alone the house of burning results caused by the causes of great fire, constantly tormented day and night, how can one crave it?
Or it is like this: afflictions, insects, and ghosts disturb and agitate, with difficult places of suffering and evil appearances, let alone this being a place of harm and burning.
In the future, the great fire of calamities and difficulties will not make this understanding, with insects and ghosts being the same as fire, what is the difference?
Difficult places have two meanings:
First, difficult to dwell in, as the Book of Poetry says, Do not disturb me, with place meaning to dwell and be at ease.
Second, a place of suffering and difficulty.
The sÅ«tra says, The children, being ignorant, play without end.
The commentary says:
This one verse is about not aspiring to take the great [vehicle].
The sÅ«tra says, At that time, the elder... up to ...increases my sorrow and distress.
The commentary says:
Below is the third section, with three verses, the metaphor of contemplating and delivering.
There are two parts:
The first verse is about increasing compassion, and the latter two verses are about contemplating and delivering.
This is the first.
Sentient beings experiencing suffering increases afflictions, further increasing the bodhisattva's compassionate mind.
Sutra: Now this house... up to setting up various expedient means.
Commentary:
Correctly thinking about the rescue.ğŸ”½Damping means to enjoy and be attached.
Immersed means to be intoxicated and confused, playing and indulging.
The rest of the meaning can be understood.
Damping and immersed are both pronounced as ding han in reverse, meaning to love and enjoy.
Playing is written as dan.
All three characters are correct.
Immersed is pronounced as wu yan in reverse, also meaning to be addicted and confused.
Ancient form: dai.
Some write it as yi and chen, not knowing where they come from.
Dai in Shuowen means to be immersed in alcohol.
Sutra: Telling the children... up to wonderful treasures and fine carriages.
Commentary:
The fourth section below has three verses, which is the analogy of expounding the three vehicles.
It is divided into three parts:
One verse is the general announcement of allowing the carriages, one verse describes the carriages being outside, and one verse explains where the carriages came from.
This is the first.
The sÅ«tra says from the sheep cart, deer cart... up to you should come out.
The commentary says:
The carts are presented outside.
The fruition emerges from the gate of causes, and the principle surpasses the teachings outside, therefore it is said to be outside the gate.
The essence of the cart is uncontaminated and unattached, called outside.
If one leaves the three realms, there is no place to bestow transformation, therefore it is outside the gate of the three vehicles.
The Buddha's house is outside, therefore he calls the children to come out.
The meaning is explained as above.
The sÅ«tra says from I will now for you... up to you can play in them.
The commentary says:
It explains the origin of the carts.
The precious place of nirvÄá¹‡a, which is unconditioned, has always existed, so it is not said that I create it;
The cart is the essence of conditioned bodhi, therefore it is said to be created.
Create means to give rise to. The ox cart of various knowledges arises from teachings and practices, therefore it is called created.
The two carts of sheep and deer are called teachings and arrangements, and it is also said that I create them.
Although they are all created, the ox-cart is created as a substance, while the sheep and deer carts are created as names, so they are all called created.
To save them in accordance with their capacities is called according to their inclinations.
The sutra says, When the children heard this, they left all the dangers and difficulties.
The commentary says:
The fourth major section below has six and a half verses, praising the analogy of escaping from danger according to the words.
It is divided into two parts:
The first one and a half verses are about the children escaping from disasters and difficulties, and the last five verses are about the father's mind being at ease.
This is the first.
Immediately rushing and competing means encouraging each other.
Running and coming out means being diligent and courageous.

Reaching the open ground means according to their respective capacities, leaving the three hindrances and dwelling in the ground of the two kinds of emptiness, which refers to the post-learners of the two vehicles and those who have entered the first ground.
It is escaping from the dangers and difficulties of the suffering of birth and death, because there is no more rebirth.
Evil results are called suffering, and evil causes are called difficulties.
The sutra says, The elder saw his children and thought, 'I am now happy.'
The commentary says:
The following five verses are about the father finally feeling at ease.
It is divided into two parts:
One and a half verses are about rejoicing upon seeing, and three and a half verses are about announcing to others upon the utmost joy.
This is the first.
Four crossroads refers to the principle of the four truths.
Since the child has come out and abides at the four crossroads, the father finally sits on the lion seat, because he has attained fearlessness and his mind is at ease.
This is because the following words At that time, the children knew that their father was sitting peacefully state that the lion seat belongs to the father.
